thread.title: Watch as Northumberland MP is moved to tears over Afghanistan veteran's plight

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Watch as Northumberland MP is moved to tears over Afghanistan veteran's plight
text:
Watch as Northumberland MP is moved to tears over Afghanistan veteran's plight Anne-Marie Trevelyan reveals scandal of 'seriously ill' veteran who received no help after returning from Afghanistan Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
A North East MP was moved to tears as she revealed the shameful way members of the armed forces are left to fend for themselves after their service ends.
Anne-Marie Trevelyan, MP for Berwick-upon-Tweed, told the House of Commons about one former soldier suffering with physical injuries and mental health problems.
He was "seriously ill" after serving in Afghanistan but had received no help from the army - and sometimes was forced to pay for private healthcare.
Mrs Trevelyan was overcome with emotion as she told the House of Commons that the former soldier's wife feared for his life.
Mrs Trevelyan, a longstanding campaigner for armed forces personnel and their families, read out a letter she had received from the soldier's wife.
It said: "There is a real risk my husband will self-harm to end his life." Read More Anne-Marie Trevelyan accused of "abandoning" constituency as she quits Government post over Brexit
The letter went into detail about the impact of post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) suffered by the soldier following his tour of Afghanistan in 2010.
It said: "I have never received any support from the military as to how I deal/manage with my husband’s PTSD.
"My husband likewise hasn’t had any contact from the Army. I just cannot comprehend this lack, and total disregard, for their duty of care."
The letter continued: "He was medically discharged for physical injuries he sustained during that tour in 2014.
"He served in Helmand as a platoon commander leading young men at a young age in an area that, without exception, was the most dangerous place in the world. Read More
"How can the army not follow up with serving members of the forces to check they are ok when people have died on patrols that they have led?
"People have lost limbs, had spinal fractures, have been injured in an IED explosion themselves.
"How can they not check that the families have the support that they need? How can they risk more potential casualties in the form of suicide?"
And the soldier's wife finished by saying she feared "this letter will be included one day as an exhibit in a bundle collated for the Coroner," a reference to her concern that her husband might kill himself. Read More
Mrs Trevelyan was forced to stop as she read this section of the letter out.
She later said: "I get far too many of those letters."
Armed forces minister Tobias Ellwood told the House of Commons he would meet with Mrs Trevelyan to discuss the issues she had raised. Like us on Facebook
